verses.text: A workman fond of wine will never grow rich, and he who despises small things will fall little by little.
verses.comment: This verse reminds us that discipline and attention to detail are needed for spiritual and material growth. Jesus also honors faithfulness in small things (Luke 16:10). Small acts done faithfully participate in building up God’s kingdom.

verses.text: Wine and women make men of understanding stumble, and he who keeps company with prostitutes grows very bold.
verses.comment: Wisdom literature often warns against the dangers of excess wine and immoral relationships. See also Proverbs 31:3 about kings avoiding such dangers. The body is a temple (1 Cor. 6:19), so purity is a deep theme.

verses.text: Moths and worms will inherit him, and a reckless soul will be snatched away.
verses.comment: Using images from nature, the verse speaks of the end of those who act recklessly. Their fate is like that of all flesh (see Job 27 and Isa. 51:8).

verses.text: One who trusts quickly is light-minded; and one who sins does wrong against himself.
verses.comment: Naiveté in trust can bring ruin, as can sin—Proverbs 14:15 echoes this: 'The simple believes every word.' Sin is always self-destructive.

verses.text: Who rejoices in evil will be condemned, but he who resists pleasures crowns his life.
verses.comment: True blessedness comes from resisting sinful pleasures. This speaks to the importance of self-mastery in the Christian walk, a theme echoed throughout the apostles’ letters (James 1:12).

verses.text: He who hates gossip lessens evil, but whoever repeats a word breaks his own peace.
verses.comment: Controlling our speech is central to wisdom (James 3:5-6). Keeping confidences is a mark of spiritual maturity.

verses.text: Do not explain the matter to friend or enemy, and unless it is a sin for you, do not reveal it.
verses.comment: Prudence in speech prevents unnecessary strife. There is a strong biblical value placed on discretion (cf. Prov. 17:9).

verses.text: For you would hear dishonor, and having heard it, your spirit will be stabbed.
verses.comment: Learning of shameful things can deeply wound. Psalm 55 expresses similar pain at betrayal.

verses.text: If you have heard a word, let it die with you. Be assured, it will not burst you.
verses.comment: Learning to keep silent preserves peace and relationships. See also Proverbs 10:19 on the wisdom of few words.

verses.text: A fool will be in labor, like a child in childbirth, to bring forth something he heard, like an arrow stuck in a man’s thigh.
verses.comment: The image here is of uncontrollable urge to gossip. Words can wound deeply, as Proverbs 18:8 teaches.

verses.text: If you hear something against your neighbor, question it well; perhaps he did not do it. And if he did do it, do not repeat it.
verses.comment: This verse anticipates Jesus’ teaching in Matthew 18:15 about first confronting a person privately. Mercy is to be shown before judgment.

verses.text: If you heard something, let it die with you; do not be afraid, it will not crush you.
verses.comment: Repeats the wisdom to keep silent, assuring that not speaking will not cause harm. Discretion is repeatedly valued in biblical wisdom literature.

verses.text: A fool will travail over a word just as a woman in labor over a child.
verses.comment: Repeats the idea that a fool cannot keep a secret; this is compared to the agony of childbirth, highlighting the power of restraint.

verses.text: Like an arrow that sticks in a man’s thigh, so is a secret in a fool’s mouth.
verses.comment: Words have power to do harm; repeated in Proverbs 26:22: 'The words of a whisperer are like delicious morsels.'

verses.text: Question a friend, maybe he did not do it, and if he did anything, so that he may not do it again.
verses.comment: This echoes Leviticus 19:17 about correcting your neighbor out of love. Restoration, not condemnation, is the purpose.

verses.text: Question your neighbor, for it may be that he did not say it, and if he did say it, that he may not say it again.
verses.comment: Once again, the need to resolve matters directly and privately is reinforced, minimizing gossip and discord.

verses.text: Question a friend, for often it is slander; do not believe everything you hear.
verses.comment: Warns against credulity and spreading slander. Discretion and seeking truth are a spiritual discipline.

verses.text: A man may slip without intending it. Who has not sinned with his tongue?
verses.comment: Acknowledges human weakness and frailty, especially concerning speech. James 3:2 echoes that 'we all stumble in many ways.'

verses.text: Blessed is the man who is protected from it, who has not slipped with his tongue, nor been wounded in sin.
verses.comment: Righteousness is shown in self-control of speech. The Psalmist prays for God to 'set a guard over my mouth.'

verses.text: There is one who keeps silent but is found wise, and another detested for much talking.
verses.comment: Consistent with the wisdom books: even a fool who remains silent is considered wise.

verses.text: One who keeps silent, not knowing what to reply, and another who keeps silent, knowing when to speak.
verses.comment: Wisdom discerns the proper time for silence and speech (Eccl. 3:7).

verses.text: A wise man will keep silent until the right time, but a chatterer and fool misses the right moment.
verses.comment: Discernment and the timing of words is a hallmark of true wisdom.

verses.text: He who speaks much will be hated; and he who takes authority upon himself will be hated.
verses.comment: Consistent with James 3:1, which warns that not many should be teachers because of stricter judgment. Humility is prized.

verses.text: There is one who brings destruction though not out of malice; lacking wisdom, he will slip.
verses.comment: Even unintended actions can cause harm. This points to the need for grace to cover sins of ignorance (see Psalm 19:12).

verses.text: There is one who keeps silent, judging as wise, and another who keeps silent, out of fear or weakness.
verses.comment: Silence can be either a mark of wisdom or of cowardice. The heart’s intent matters.

verses.text: A man who covers his mouth pretends to be righteous, but his inward heart is revealed.
verses.comment: Jesus echoes this—what proceeds from the heart defiles a man (see Matt. 15:18). Both words and silence can mask the real heart.

verses.text: There is one who turns away his face and pretends not to hear, but when you are not watching, he will take advantage of you.
verses.comment: Warns against dissemblance and deceit—Proverbs 16:28: 'A dishonest man spreads strife.'

verses.text: If for lack of power he is prevented from sinning, if he finds an opportunity, he will do evil.
verses.comment: Guarding the heart is primary; righteousness is more than avoiding sin by chance. It must be chosen intentionally.

verses.text: A man is known by his appearance, and a wise man's face is known by his countenance.
verses.comment: External appearance can reveal much, yet only God sees the heart (1 Sam. 16:7; cf. Eccl. 8:1 on wisdom's effect on the face).

verses.text: A man’s clothing, a smile, and how he walks show what he is.
verses.comment: As Jesus says, 'By their fruits you will know them' (Matthew 7:20). Wisdom literature values outward expression that flows from inner virtue.
